intro: Sipanea carrenoi, commonly known as the Sierra Madre cypress, is a rare and endemic coniferous species native to the high-altitude regions of the Sierra Madre Occidental in western Mexico. It is characterized by its slender, columnar growth habit and needle-like leaves that are typically dark green and arranged in spirals. The plant produces small, scale-like cones that contain wind-dispersed seeds, a reproductive strategy adapted to its mountainous habitat. Sipanea carrenoi thrives in cool, moist environments with well-drained soils, often growing in association with other high-altitude flora. Due to habitat loss and limited distribution, it is considered a vulnerable species requiring conservation efforts to ensure its survival.
